Now that the season is over, I want to see the most overpowered, improperly spec’d, and absurd uses of a CIM-class motor that you encountered during Reefscape.

What qualifies as a CIM class motor?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T02:44:17.326Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":531,"readers_count":530,"score":111.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500100,"topic_slug":"most-ridiculous-use-of-a-cim-class-motor","display_username":"Jared Van Horn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51417,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alum/NJIT Student"},"post_url":"/t/most-ridiculous-use-of-a-cim-class-motor/500100/2","custom_user_title":"Alum/NJIT Student","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3599489,"name":"Erik Boyle","username":"Ekcrbe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekcrbe/{size}/221615_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T02:49:34.260Z","cooked":"

Any motor with the CIM mounting pattern, #10-32 holes on a 2" bolt circle. That includes (by rough order of release date iirc):

  • CIM
  • Mini CIM
  • NEO
  • Falcon 500
  • Kraken X60
  • NEO Vortex

A team I know used redline motors for their elevator while using a kraken for their coral intake.

Funny that we just made a post about this mechanism. A NEO Vortex spinning a lead screw ~1.5 rotations to engage a friction brake.

FRC 6995: NOMAD 2025 CAD Release CAD
Sure! Below is a section view with all of the labeled components. [Screenshot 2025-04-21 at 6.21.29 PM] The vortex is driving a WCP rubber friction brake on an 8mm lead screw. This gets pushed into a lathed down aluminum hex hub, which is on the same shaft as one of our gears for the pivot (early in the reduction so minimal force is needed). In the gif below you can see the very small range of motion, and where the rubber pad and hex hub interfere (the red). [Screen Recording Apr 21 2025] A…

I will defend this as a solid design decision based on the utility of the spinning shell and sacrificial shaft for the coupler, but I doubt we needed the power.

kinda the reverse of this, but there was a team at UTWV with a 2-Redline elevator. In fact all of their motors besides their drivetrain (standard mk4 IIRC) were redlines.

Well it was not for Reefscape, but back in 2018 one of our students made what could be the most ridiculous CIM based mechanism of all time. We needed a brake to keep our elevator from drifting down when the power was turned off. So he made an air brake by cutting the wires off a CIM, cutting a hole in the case and putting a small pancake pneumatic cylinder on it to lock the spindle in place. IIRC the crazy thing used a 2 CIM gear box where one drove the elevator up and the other toggled on with the brake when power to the drive motor stopped. We had every inspector at Lake Superior looking it over…and I think some from Northern Lights too!


So many yellow hats trying to figure this thing out!
